Embracing a healthy lifestyle involves eating well, staying active, and taking care of your mental well-being.

A healthy diet 
A healthy diet involves eating a variety of foods in the correct proportions and consuming a calorie intake that allows for the maintenance of healthy body weight. Although this varies for everyone, as a general guide, this should include: 

	a. Five portions of fruit and vegetables per day 
	b. Lean proteins, especially fish, eggs, and white meat, are essential for cellular repair and provide a range of vitamins and minerals 
	c. Dairy foods and their alternatives, which are a good source of protein and provide calcium. 
	d. Starchy foods, particularly wholegrain varieties which contain more fiber and nutrients 
	e. Limited amounts of unsaturated fats.

Physical activity \nThe World Health Organisation recommends that all adults undertake regular physical activity, including at least thirty minutes of moderate aerobic activity daily, supplemented by at least two weight-bearing activity sessions per week. \n

Sleep \nTry to get 7-8 hours every night and try to keep a regular sleep-wake cycle – go to bed and get up at the same time every day. A good nights sleep may make you more productive and efficient on the next day.\n

Drink Plenty of Water \nOur body is 75% water and it is necessary to maintain the amount of liquid we consume, especially water as it is the most vital liquid humans require. 8 glasses a day also equal to 3 litres of water a day should keep you hydrated and healthy. \n

Socialise \nHaving a healthy diet and exercising aren\'t the only contributors in having a healthy lifestyle, socialise with your peers and have some fun once in a while to keep yourself (mind and body) healthy and free of stress\n

Many people equate hygiene with "cleanliness", but hygiene is a broad term. It includes such personal habit choices as how frequently to take a shower or bath, wash hands, trim fingernails, and wash clothes. It also includes attention to keeping surfaces in the home and workplace clean, including bathroom facilities.\n So, when did it all start?

The history of hygiene spans civilizations, evolving from early practices like ancient bathing rituals to the modern understanding of germ theory, prompting advancements in sanitation, clean water access, and public health measures.

The exploration of pivotal scientific moments in cleanliness history involves significant milestones, such as the discovery of bacteria by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek in the 17th century, revolutionizing our understanding of hygiene and prompting advancements in public health measures.

Microbes are like the superheroes and villains of our body—they help with digestion but can also cause diseases. Learning about them is like uncovering a tiny, invisible world that impacts our health!

The exploration of the human microbiome, the vast community of microbes living in and on our bodies, has been a recent focus. This area of research has unveiled surprising connections between microbial communities and our health, influencing everything from our immune system to mental well-being. \n\nUnderstanding the microbial world has transformed hygiene practices. From the development of effective antibiotics to the implementation of stringent sterilization techniques, STEM-driven innovations have significantly improved sanitation standards, minimizing the risk of infectious diseases.

Now that we know more about hygiene, how do we practice living a clean and hygienic lifestyle?\nIts easy, make sure to always take care of your personal hygiene by washing your wash every morning and evening, brushing your teeth for at least 3 times a day and taking a bath for a minimum of 2 times a day. Always remember to wash your hands and feet to prevent the unwanted microorganisms entering your body.
